Bug in apache 2.0.44 win32 (observed in more early apache2 versions). 
mod_autoindex alway return web-pages in UTF-8 encoding igoring these 
parameters in httpd.conf:

AddLanguage ru .ru
LanguagePriority ru en da nl et fr de el it ja ko no pl pt pt-br ltz ca es sv 
tw
AddCharset WINDOWS-1251 .cp-1251 .win-1251 
AddDefaultCharset WINDOWS-1251

text:
this is intended under win32 (nt+), because of the unicode filesystem.
I can't see, why this is a bug? What has it to do with your mod_mime configuration?

I have AddDescription in .htaccess with comments in russian encoding (cp1251). 
My browser didn't detect encoding, therefore I see hieroglyphics :) For this 
reason I have to change view encoding in my browser manualy to Windows-1251.

text: Andre, take a look here: http://tty.net.ru/slava

oh, well, I see the problem :)

I guess we should resp. the charset resp. make it configurable and make more use
of the capabilities of HTML (character references) instead of a raw encoding.

Current workaround is (obviously): encode the .htaccess as utf-8 instead of cp1251.

Thanks for the report and thanks for using Apache!

text:
I've leeched new version of Apache - 2.0.45, the problem still presents. Someone 
could fix that bug?

Maybe there should be a new directive for mod_autoindex, like "FileNameCharset",
so the general charset of auto-generated indexes defaults to the charset given
by "AddDefaultCharset", and the file names are interpreted in the charset given
by "FileNameCharset".  "FileNameCharset" could be hard-coded as Unicode on Win32.

Example:

AddDefaultCharset ISO-8859-1
FileNameCharset UTF-8

This would make mod_autoindex send the page as ISO-8859-1, and recode the file
names from UTF-8 to ISO-8859-1, encoding any non-ISO-8859-1 characters as HTML
entities (&#xxxx;).

Thinking a bit more about this, "FileNameCharset" probably would make sense as a
general Apache core directive (not just a mod_autoindex one), so Apache would
know how to interpret file and directory names in certain (or all) directories.
creator: julian@mehnle.net

text:
Since 2.0.63 you can use Charset= to have mod_autoindex report
a different charset for the page.

That still doesn't do much in the case where filenames, or included files 
(e.g. HeaderName header.html), use a different char set.
